thread.title: Many New York-Area Services Shut as Latest Nor’easter Hits

author: Paul Berger
title: Many New York-Area Services Shut as Latest Nor’easter Hits
text:
5 COMMENTS Many New Yorkers woke up Wednesday to the fourth nor’easter this month, with heavy, wet snow and strong winds disrupting travel around the region.
Many flights and rail services in the Northeast were canceled in anticipation of the storm that was expected to dump up to 18 inches of snow on the city and its New Jersey suburbs.
Dan Petersen, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service, said that snow could fall at a rate of one to 2 inches per hour in the mid- to late afternoon as winds gust up to 45 miles an hour.
“This is a high-impact event,” Mr. Petersen said. “It’s going to cause considerable blowing of snow, sharply reducing visibility.”
In a morning news conference in Manhattan, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said he was “very dissatisfied” with how utility companies managed a storm earlier this month and called the delays in getting power back on “inexcusable.” He warned utility companies to respond rapidly this time and suggested he would support revoking their authority to deliver power if they don’t.
“Utility companies were not granted a license by God,” he added. “It’s not in the Old Testament that these utility companies have to have their licenses. If they’re not performing for New Yorkers, they can lose their licenses, and we’re fully prepared to do that.”
Earlier this month, thousands of homes remained without power in New York and New Jersey for days after a powerful nor’easter hit the region.
The governor also cautioned New Yorkers to avoid travel, saying the weather will get worse throughout the day and that the predicted wind gusts could cause accidents.
As of Wednesday morning, about 3,500 flights had been canceled nationally. Most of them were at New York’s three hubs, John F. Kennedy International, LaGuardia and Newark Liberty International airports, where about 70% of flights were canceled.
Amtrak operated a reduced schedule on many lines, including its busy Northeast Corridor line between Washington, D.C., and Boston.
In New York City, the subway and buses ran with minor delays and disruptions Wednesday morning. The Long Island Rail Road operated a regular weekday schedule, but officials asked riders to leave the city as early as possible this afternoon because worsening weather could cause services to be suspended.

In New Jersey, Gov. Phil Murphy declared a state of emergency and ordered state offices to close. NJ Transit operated a reduced rail schedule Wednesday morning and warned that bus service into the Port Authority Bus Terminal, in Manhattan could be suspended in the afternoon.
Many schools across New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were closed Wednesday. Shutting New York City schools Wednesday meant the district’s administration of free SAT tests in high schools was postponed a month. City teenagers anxious to get the college entry exams over with will have to wait until Tuesday April 24.
—Leslie Brody contributed to this article.
